(2 )
Mr. S.. Morgan, President, New York. Sept. 24th.
1) In my opinion Howard is qualified for the position
for which he is applying.
2) I do not believe that a second man is necessary at this
this time.
If we should commence operations
to Manila
and Trans-Pacific, a Devision Manager would be required
to cover a very extensive system, and there should be
in my opinion a competent man in cherge at all times
at Shanghai or where ever our Far Eastern headquarters
may be established.
3) If Howard should be selected, I think a fair and adequate
compensation for him would be the same salary
which he
drew from the Department of Commerce, the amount of which
you can easily determine by consulting Leighton Rogers.
The figure which Howard mentioned of G.$7,500 appears to
me about
correct, and would have the additional merit of
under him, This whole
upon my
return to New York along with many other problems
having to do with personel and organization.
If in your opinion it is advisable to employ Howard now
because of other offers he is considering or for any
other reason, I would suggest that he be given an opportu-
nity to nity to fly over the greater part of the routes operated
by the Pan Anerican system, and be also given a thorough
training in Pan American methods, executive,
engineering,
operations, comminications and traffic, and
that he then
be sent to
china with a view of developing him as a No.2
man in
the Far East division, fully capable of filling
the No.l position.
At this point,
I believe that it is my duty to say to
you at the present writing
that I am entirely satisfied with the
position which I occupy in the Pan American organization, that I
believe that we shall be successful in our negotiations,
and that
I shall be very glad of an oppotunity to return to the Far East
for the Company.
It is my desire to complete the contracts
which I was sent over here to negotiate and
then return to New
York for the purpose of discussing,
in details many problems of
an economical, political and organzing nature which cannot be
carried
out by correspendence.
I would then like to have
an @portunity to caciver
above outlined for Howard.
pon to the too of the one
would then like to return to the
Far East bringing Mrs. Bixby and our teo youngest daughters with
us, leaving
the two older girls at Farmington to finish their
education.
I am writing so agh fully concerning my personal
affairs because I believe that you are entitled to know what
I have in my mind for the future, ani so far as that programme
may
effect
the Company's business.
It appears now as though I
will not be able to complete the work here in less than two
months as a minimum.
